section.title: Present Perfect Simple with just, yet and already
section.sectiontitle: You can use just, yet and already with the Present Perfect Simple. Form the Present Perfect Simple with has/have + past participle.
section.text1a: Andy has already started to annoy me.
section.sectiontitle2: Just means a short time ago. Just usually comes between has/have and the past participle.
section.text3a: I've just seen a really great film.

section.title: Present Perfect Simple with just, yet and already
section.sectiontitle: Already shows that something happened sooner than the speaker expected. Already usually comes between has/have and the past participle or at the end of the sentence.
section.text2a: He's taken his driving test six times already.
section.sectiontitle2: Yet usually comes at the end of questions and negative sentences. Yet means 'until now' and shows that the speaker is expecting something to happen.
section.text4a: I haven't got the tickets yet.
